questions.text: Changes in which of the following does not affect respiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Arterial Na+ concentration
Changes in arterial Na+ does not have any effect on respiration. Increase in arterial H+ stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors increasing the rate and depth of ventilation. Increase in arterial pCO2 stimulates both the central and peripheral chemoreceptors increasing the rate and depth of ventilation. Increase in arterial HCO3- or alkalosis suppresses the respiratory drive.

questions.text:
The following events occur in the carotid bodies on exposure to hypoxia are listed in random order:
(1) release of dopamine
(2) excitation of afferent fibres of ninth nerve 
(3) depolarization of glomus cells
(4) decreased potassium conductance through O2 sensitive potassium channels on glomus cells 
(5) opening of voltage gated calcium channels and calcium influx
What is the correct sequence in which the above occur on exposure to hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
On exposure to hypoxia, there is closure and decreased potassium conductance through O2 sensitive potassium channels on glomus cells. Accumulation of positive charge within the glomus cells depolarizes the cells. This leads to opening of voltage gated calcium channels and calcium influx. Increase in intracellular calcium causes release of dopamine by the glomus cells. Dopamine combines with its receptors (D2) on the ninth nerve terminal, exciting the nerve terminals. Impulses go to the respiratory centre in the medulla resulting in an increase in rate and depth of ventilation.

choices.text: Shift of OHDC to the right
Decrease in the number of mitochondria

questions.text: Acclimatization to high altitude includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Acclimatization to high altitude is due to the operation of a number of compensatory mechanisms.
These include:-
- Increased urinary excretion of bicarbonates. High altitude results in hypoxic hypoxia stimulating the peripheral chemoreceptors. The resulting hyperventilation results in respiratory alkalosis. Alkalosis suppresses the chemoreceptor response. Kidneys increase the urinary excretion of bicarbonates reducing the pH bringing it back towards normal. This increases the response to hypoxia.
- Shift of OHDC to the right- respiratory alkalosis at high altitude causes a shift of the OHDC to the left, but a concomitant increase in red blood cell 2,3- DPG shifts the OHDC to the right. The net effect is shift to right and a small increase in P50.
- Increased secretion of erythropoietin- hypoxia is potent stimulus for secretion of EPO from the kidneys.
- Hypoxia causes increase in the number of mitochondria, which are the site of oxidative
reactions. 
-Myoglobin also increases which facilitates the movement of O2 to the tissues. The tissue
content of cytochrome enzymes also increases.

questions.text: Which of the following will cause the OHDC to shift to the left?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
CO decreases 2,3-DPG causing a shift of the OHDC to the left.
In high altitude, hypoxic hypoxia stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors producing a
hyperventilation. This results in a respiratory alkalosis, shifting the OHDC to the left. But in high altitude there is increased production of 2,3-DPG. The net result, therefore, is a slight increase in P50 and a shift of the curve to the right.
Anemia increases 2,3- DPG and shifts the OHDC to the right.
Exercise also causes increase in 2,3- DPG and shift of the OHDC to the right but this occurs only in untrained athletes

questions.text: Shown below is an electron microscopic picture of a sarcomere. Which of the following represent the H-zone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
A is the dark or A (anisotropic to light) band which consists of myosin and overlapped actin.
B is half of I band. I band consists of only actin.
C is the sarcomere. Sarcomere is the structural and functional unit of skeletal muscle. 
Within the A-band there is lighter area called the H-zone (D), which consists of only myosin.

questions.text: TF/ P (tubular fluid/ plasma) ratio at the end of PCT will be maximum for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
TF/P ratio for non- reabsorbable substance like Inulin is 2.5 to 3.3 at the end of PCT. It follows that 60-70% of the filtered solutes and 60-70% of the filtered water have been removed by the time the filtrate reaches the end of PCT. Since inulin is freely filtered, not reabsorbed or secreted, there is a progressive increase in Inulin concentration in the PCT, so that its TF/P ratio at the end of the PCT is highest among the four given options. Substance like PAH, which is freely filtered and completely secreted in the PCT, will have a TF/P ratio higher than Inulin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least susceptible to local anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
A gamma is most susceptible to local anaesthetics and type C fibers are the least susceptible.

questions.text: Most important buffer in the interstitial fluid is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The principal buffer in the interstitial fluid is bicarbonate.

questions.text: Parathormone increases calcium reabsorption in which of the following segments of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
PTH increases calcium absorption in the DCT. But the maximum calcium absorption takes place in the PCT. PTH decreases absorption of inorganic phosphorus in the PCT (k/a phosphaturic action of PTH).

questions.text: The receptors responsible for rapid, shallow breathing are
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
J or juxtacapillary receptors located at the alveolo- capillary junction are stimulated by
• Pulmonary congestion
• Pulmonary edema
• Pulmonary embolism
Stimulation of the J receptors results in
• Apnea followed by rapid, shallow ventilation
• Hypotension
• Bradycardia
Pulmonary stretch receptors are responsible for HeringBreur Reflex.
Chemoreceptor stimulation causes increase in rate and depth of ventilation.
Receptors for tidal respiration are muscle spindles in the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

choices.text: Can be blocked by specific transporters

questions.text: Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion share which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion are examples of passive transport and therefore, do not require energy for transport.

questions.text: The receptors for the Hering- Breur reflex are located in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The receptors for the HeringBreur reflex are located in the tracheobronchial tree. They respond to increased stretch, when the tidal volume increases to 2-3 times normal, and the response is to limit inspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms for transport across the luminal cell membrane of an enterocyte is present in newborns and infants but not in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Intestinal absorption of immunoglobulins (in colostrum) during early infancy occurs by
endocytosis. This ability to absorb large molecules by endocytosis occurs during the first several months of life but is lost thereafter. Simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, primary and secondary active transports are all normal processes in enterocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following has an intranuclear receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Insulin is a water soluble hormone and therefore, it has a membrane surface receptor.
Cortisol, aldosterone, progesterone, testosterone have cytoplasmic receptors.
Thyroid hormones and estrogen have nuclear receptors.

questions.text: Hyperbaric oxygen causes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Hyperbaric oxygen works by increasing the DISSOLVED component of oxygen in the blood. The
result will be
-	Increased arterial PO2
-	Increased oxygen content in blood
-	Increased tissue PO2
-	No change in arterial pH or CO2 
Indications for hyperbaric oxygen are:_
• Air embolism
• Decompression sickness
• CO poisoning
• Burns
• Crush injuries
• Compromised skin flaps
• Radiation necrosis
• Necrotizing infections
• Gas gangrene
• Intracranial abscess

questions.text: Most abundant anion in the ICF is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 
misclellaneous phosphates
In the ICF, miscellaneous phosphates > proteins.

questions.text: The most important factor which determines the movement of a permeant substance across the cell membrane is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 
lipid solubility
Diffusion coefficient of a substance is determined mainly by the lipid solubility of that substance.

questions.text: The equation which is used to calculate the magnitude of the equilibrium potential of a freely diffusible ion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Nernst equation
Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This is the Gibbs Donnan Equation.
If a membrane is freely permeable to an ion, magnitude of potential difference for that ion at equilibrium (equilibrium potential or Nernst potential) can be calcuklated by the Nernst Equation. 
Goldmann Hodgkin Katz equation is used to calculate the RMP.
Henderson Hasselbach equation is used to calculate the pH of a buffer solution containing given concentrations of an acid and its conjugate base.

choices.text: Restoration of ionic balance after an action potential

questions.text: The most important function of Na+ K+ ATPase is which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
cell volume regulation
Because of Charged proteins in cells, there are more osmotically active particles inside the cell than in the interstitial fluid. Osmosis will cause them to swell and eventually rupture if it were not for the Na+ K+ ATPase pumping ions back out of cells.

questions.text: Equilibrium potential for Na+ is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
+60mV
ENais +61mV. EK is -90mV. EClis -70mV. ECais +125mV.

choices.text: They move proteins, organelles, etc from one part of the cell to another
There are three super families of molecular motors: kinesin, dynein and myosin
Kinesins move their cargo towards the ‘-‘ end or ‘disassembly’ end of the microtubules.

questions.text: All of the following are true about molecular motors except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Kinesins move their cargo towards the ‘-‘ end or ‘disassembly’ end of the microtubules. 
Kinesins move their cargo towards the ‘+’ or assembly end of microtubules.

questions.text: Depolarization phase of the action potential is due Ca2+ influx in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Vascular muscle

Ca2+ influx is responsible for depolarization phase of the action potential in pacemaker cells of the heart and in smooth muscle.

questions.text: Normal mean systemic filling pressure is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

7 mm Hg

If the heart stops beating or circulation comes to a standstill, pressure in all systemic vessels will equilibrate (arterial pressure will fall and venous pressure will rise until an equilibrium is reached throughout the circulation). This equilibrium pressure is called the ‘mean systemic filling pressure’. It represents the distending pressure of all vessels in the circulation at a particular blood volume and level of vascular tone. It is approximately equal to the capacitance of the peripheral circulation times the blood volume. Since the capacitance of the veins is 18 to 20 times greater than that of the arteries, this pressure is largely a function of the venous system. The mean systemic filling pressure is normally in the range of 6-8 mm Hg. It is influenced by (i) blood volume and (ii) the tone of the veins.

questions.text: Maximum percentage of cardiac output is to which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

kidney

Kidney receives 22-23% of cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pulmonary vascular resistance during exercise?
questions.solution:
​​​​​​Correct Answer (C) 

increases and then decreases

At the start of exercise there is an increase in sympathetic discharge which causes a pulmonary vasoconstriction and increases the pulmonary vascular resistance. Because of opening of previously closed pulmonary capillaries, this is followed by a decrease in resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following are present in the type I glomus cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

O2-sensitive K+ channels

Type I glomus cells have O2-sensitive K+ channels, whose conductance is reduced in proportion to the degree of hypoxia to which they are exposed. This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ influx, primarily via L-type Ca2+ channels. The Ca2+ influx triggers action potentials and transmitter (Dopamine) release, with consequent excitation of the afferent nerve endings of the ninth nerve.

The smooth muscle of pulmonary arteries contains similar O2-sensitive K+ channels, which mediate the vasoconstriction caused by hypoxia. This is in contrast to systemic arteries, which contain adenosine triphosphate- (ATP-) dependent K+ channels that permit more K+ efflux with hypoxia and consequently cause vasodilation instead of vasoconstriction.

questions.text: The lung volume at the end of a maximum inspiration is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

total lung capacity

Lung volume at the end of maximum inspiration is total lung capacity.

choices.text: Arterial Pco2 may fall as low as 15 mm Hg
Alveolar Po2 increases to 120-140 mm Hg
Cerebral blood flow reduces  by 30% or more

questions.text: All of the following are effects of hyperventilation except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Blood pH decreases to 7.3 or 7.2

During voluntary hyperventilation arterial Pco2 may fall as low as 15 mm Hg, alveolar Po2 increases to 120-140 mm Hg and cerebral blood flow reduces by 30% or more because of the direct vasoconstrictor effect of hypocapnia on cerebral blood vessels. The cerebral ischemia causes light headedness, dizziness, and paresthesias. Voluntary hyperventilation causes a CO2 washout resulting in a respiratory alkalosis

choices.text: Cardiac output per kg body weight
Cardiac output per sq m of body surface area

questions.text: Cardiac index is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Cardiac output per sq m of body surface area

Cardiac index is defined as cardiac output per square meter of body surface area and it averages 3.2L/min/sq meter.

choices.text: Increases the amplitude of the action potential
Decreases the amplitude of the action potential
Resting membrane potential becomes more negative
Resting membrane potential becomes more positive

questions.text: Decrease in ECF sodium has which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Decreases the amplitude of the action potential

Decrease in ECF sodium decreases the height of the action potential but has little effect on the RMP. This is because the cell membrane at rest is almost impermeable to sodium. Sodium, therefore, does not contribute significantly to the resting membrane potential.

questions.text: Given below is the myogram of a single muscle twitch. What is the tetanizing frequency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

35- 40 Hz

Tetanizing frequency is 1/contraction period (seconds).

Here the contraction period is 25milliseconds or 25/1000 second.

Tetanizing frequency will, therefore, be 1000/25 per second or 40 Hz.

choices.text: Increase in force of contraction of the heart

questions.text: Increase in sympathetic stimulation causes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

increase in venous compliance

Increase in sympathetic stimulation causes a venoconstriction and a decrease in venous compliance, which increases venous return.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect for La Place’s law? (T is wall tension, P is distending pressure, r is radius and w is the wall thickness)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

P = 2r/T

La Place’s law states that for a thin walled viscus

T = Pr (if it is a cylinder) or P = T/r

T = Pr/2 (if it is a sphere) or P = 2T/r

If wall thickness (w) is significant, then

T = Pr/w (If it is a cylinder)

T = Pr/2w (if it is a sphere)

questions.text: The duration of nodal delay in the human heart is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

92 msec

The duration of nodal delay is 92 millisecond or 0.09 sec.  This delay is because the AV nodal fibres are small diameter and they have very few or no gap junctions.

questions.text: If the radius of a vessel is increased by 50% flow increases by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

5 times

Flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of radius. If the radius is increased by 50%, the new radius is 3/2. Flow, therefore, increases by 5 times.

choices.text: Total number of actin myosin cross bridges

questions.text: At optimum length all are maximum except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

passive tension

Passive tension increases even if the initial length is beyond optimum length. All others are maximum at optimum length.

questions.text: The circuit shown below has an inflow pressure of 120 mm Hg and an outflow pressure of 40 mm Hg. Resistance in each of the four vessels is 2 mm Hg/mL/min. What is the total peripheral resistance of the circuit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

0.5 mm Hg/mL/min

For a circuit in parallel, the total resistance decreases. 1/R = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3 +……

questions.text: Shown below is ‘chloride shift’ in RBC. What is the name of the carrier protein involved in this shift?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

AE-1

AE-1, also k/a band 3 protein is involved in chloride shift.

questions.text: If an artery is partially occluded by an embolus such that its radius becomes one- half the pre-occlusion value, which of the following parameters will decrease by a factor of 16?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

blood flow.

Blood flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of radius. Decrease in radius to half reduces the flow to 1/16th of its pre occlusion value.

choices.text: Sensory fiber from golgi tendon organ

questions.text: Least conduction velocity is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

pre- ganglionic autonomic

Pre-ganglionic autonomic fibers are type B. All others are type A fibers. Type B has least conduction velocity.

questions.text: FRC is the lung volume after which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

normal expiration

FRC is the volume of air which remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

questions.text:
The following measurements are obtained in a 30-year-old male patient:

Systemic arterial O2: 0.19mL O2/mL

Pulmonary artery O2: 0.14mL O2/mL

Whole body oxygen consumption: 250mL/min

What is the patient’s cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

5.00L/min

Calculation of cardiac output by the Fick’s Principle.

Fick’s principle states that

Cardiac output (L/min) = O2 consumption (in mL/min)/arterio venous O2 difference in mL/L

                                             = 250mL/min / (190 – 140) mL/L = 250/50 L/min = 5 L/min

questions.text:
Regional variations in ventilation (V) and perfusion (Q) are measured in healthy individuals when they stand in the upright position. The results are graphed with x-axis denoting the position along the lung from the base to the apex.

Which of the curves is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ventilation and blood flow decrease from base to apex, but the V/Q ratio increases from base to apex.

questions.text: A patient with respiratory volume of 500 ml. The intrapleural pressure measured is -4 cm of H2O before inspiration and -8cm of H2O at the end of inspiration. The pulmonary compliance of the patient is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

125 mL/cm H20

Lung Compliance and Elastic Forces

  • Due to tendency of tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed
  • At the resting (muscles relaxed) volume (FRC), the tendency of the isolated lungs is to collapse (lung recoil is towards the inside) and the tendency of the isolated chest wall is to expand (chest wall recoil is towards the outside). Relaxed intrapleural pressure (Ppl) at FRC is negative, about -4 cm H20

 

Compliance

The ability of the lungs and pleural cavity to change in volume based on changes in pressure

Definition: C=∆V / ∆P

  • Compliance is change in volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure
  • So, in this question,

Compliance = 500/4 = 125ml/cm H20

questions.text: The oxygen carrying capacity of a 18-years-old boy with hemoglobin of 14g/dl is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

18mL/dL                               

Theoretically the maximum oxygen that can be transported by 1gm of Hb is 1.39 ml O2, but direct measurement gives a capacity of 1.34 ml O2/g Hb. 1.34 is also known as Hüfner’s constant.

The oxygen content of blood is the volume of oxygen in mL transported in each 100 ml blood. It is calculated by: (O2 carried by Hb) + (O2 in solution) = (1.34xHbxSpO2x0.01) + (0.003xPaO2)

Where:

  • SO2 = percentage saturation of Hb with oxygen
  • Hb = haemoglobin concentration in grams pre 100 ml blood
  • PO2 = partial pressure of oxygen
  • .003 mL/dL is the solubility of oxygen

 

OXYGEN CARRYING CAPACITY OF HEMOGLOBIN

  • Each gram of haemoglobin transport 1.34 mL of oxygen

So, here in the question, its 14x1.34=18mL of oxygen

questions.text: Calculate FEV1 from the below spirometry reading
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

80%

FORCED VITAL CAPACITY (FVC)

  • It is the volume of air in litres that can be forcefully and maximally exhaled after a maximal inspiration

 

Forced Expiratory Volume in the 1st Second (FEV1)

  • It is the volume of air that is exhaled in the 1st second of the FVC
  • Normally it is around 70- 80% of the FVC

In this question,

  • FVC=5L
  • FEV1=4L

So, FEV1=4/5-80% of FVC

questions.text:
The following graph shows the transport kinetics of a solute transferredacross cell membrane.

What is the likely nature of the solute?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

glucose. 

Since carrier proteins tend to get saturated all carrier mediated transports will have a transport maxima. Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion which is carrier mediated. Therefore, transport of glucose will show a transport maxima.

questions.text: What is the best way to maintain blood flow to a tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

increase vessel diameter

Flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of radius. Increasing the vessel diameter will cause the largest increase in flow.

choices.text: Voltage gated sodium and potassium channels
Ligand gated sodium and potassium channels

questions.text: Acetylcholine receptors at the neuro-muscular junctions are
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

ligand gated sodium and potassium channels

The impulse arriving at the end of the A alpha motor neurone causes release of acetylcholine. Acetylcholine diffuses to nicotinic cholinergic (NM) receptors that are concentrated at the tops of the junctional folds of the membrane of the motor endplate. Binding of acetylcholine to these receptors increases the Na+ and K+ conductance, though the movement of sodium predominates. The resultant influx of Na+ produces a depolarizing potential, the endplate potential. The current sink created by this local potential depolarizes the adjacent muscle membrane to its firing level. Action potentials are generated on either side of the endplate and are conducted away from the endplate in both directions along the muscle fiber. The muscle action potential, in turn, initiates muscle contraction. Acetylcholine is then removed from the synaptic cleft by acetylcholinesterase, which is present in high concentration at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the spread of depolarization in the ventricles
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Septum, endocardium, epicardium

Depolarization of the ventricular muscle starts at the left side of the interventricular septum and moves first to the right across the mid portion of the septum. The wave of depolarization then spreads down the septum to the apex of the heart. It returns along the ventricular walls to the AV groove, proceeding from the endocardial to the epicardial surface. The last parts of the heart to be depolarized are the posterobasal portion of the left ventricle, the pulmonary conus, and the uppermost portion of the septum.

choices.text: It is produced in alveolar type I cells and secreted into the alveolus.
It is increased in the lungs of heavy smokers.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes surfactant lining the alveoli?
questions.solution:
Crrect Answer (A) 

Helps prevent alveolar collapse.

With expiration as the alveolar size decreases, concentration of surfactant molecules per unit area increases. The low surface tension when the alveoli are small is due to the presence of surfactant in the fluid lining the alveoli. Surfactant is a mixture of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC), other lipids, and proteins. If the surface tension is not kept low when the alveoli become smaller during expiration, they collapse in accordance with the law of Laplace. In spherical structures like an alveolus, the distending pressure (P) equals two times the tension (T) divided by the radius (r; P = 2T/r); if T is not reduced as r is reduced, the tension overcomes the distending pressure. Surfactant also helps prevent pulmonary edema. It has been calculated that if it were not present, the unopposed surface tension in the alveoli would produce a 20 mm Hg force; such a force would greatly favor transudation of fluid from the blood into the alveoli.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B respectively from the conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Na+, K+

questions.text: Baroreceptor is which type of feedback?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

negative feedback

Increase in blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors which in turn decreases sympathetic outflow lowering the blood pressure. Fall in bp decreases baroreceptor stimulation which in turn increases sympathetic outflow increasing the blood pressure. In both cases there is a reversal of the initiating stimulus. Reversal of the initiating stimulus is a characteristic feature of negative feedback.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for BezoldJarish Reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Serotonin                                            

BEZOLD-JARISCH REFLEX

  • Intracardiac injections of chemicals like serotonin, veratridine, capsaicin, phenyldiguanide activates this reflex
  • Afferents for this reflex travel through unmyelinated vagal C fiber endings
  • The reflex responses are:
  • Apnea followed by rapid breathing
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Clinical importance of Bezold-Jarisch reflex
  • This reflex is responsible for sinus bradycardia seen during myocardial infarction

This reflex is one of the cause for profound bradycardia and circulatory collapse after spinal anesthesia

questions.text: Respiratory rhythm generation centeris locatedinwhich of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Pre- Bottzinger complex

The Pre Bottzinger complex is the pacemaker of respiration or the respiratory rhythm generator.

questions.text: In the relaxed state, chest wall recoil and lung recoil are equal and opposite at which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

FRC

At FRC, chest wall recoil and lung recoil are equal and opposite to each other. FRC is also k/a the relaxation volume of the lungs.

questions.text: On standing from sitting position a person has a fall in BP of 10mm Hg.After correction, the baroreceptor mechanism corrects the bp by8mm Hg with anerror of 2mm Hg. What is gain of the baroreceptor system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

4

Gain = correction/ error = 8/2 = 4.

questions.text: Which of the following is a midbrain reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

head-on-body righting reflex

All righting reflexes are integrated in the midbrain except visual and labyrinthine righting.

choices.text: Decrease in plasma osmolality, decrease in blood volume
Increase in plasma osmolality, increase in blood volume
Increase in plasma osmolality, decrease in blood volume
Decrease in plasma osmolality, increase in blood volume

questions.text: Thirst is stimulated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Increase in plasma osmolality, decrease in blood volume

Increase in plasma osmolality stimulates the osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus, which in turn sends excitatory impulses to the supraoptic nucleus increasing ADH secretion. A decrease in blood volume decreases the stimulation of the atrial stretch receptors, increasing ADH secretion.

choices.text: Basket cells release glutamate to activate Purkinje cells.
Climbing fiber inputs exert a strong excitatory effect on Purkinje cells, and mossy fiber inputs exert a strong inhibitory effect on Purkinje cells.
Granule cells release glutamate to excite basket cells and stellate cells.
The axons of Purkinje cells are the sole output of the cerebellar cortex, and they release glutamate to excite the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct description of connections involving cerebellar neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Granule cells release glutamate to excite basket cells and stellate cells.

Granule cells are the only excitatory neuron in the cerebellum. They secrete glutamate which excites the basket cells and stellate cells.

Basket and stellate are inhibitory and they inhibit the Purkinje cells.

choices.text: Transection of left half of the spinal cord in the upper thoracic region.
Transection of sensory and motor pathways on the right side of the pons.
Transection of the right half of the spinal cord in the upper thoracic region.
Transection of the dorsal half of the spinal cord in the upper thoracic region.

questions.text: After a road traffic accident, a young man is foundto have partial loss of voluntary movement on the right side of his body and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side below the midthoracic region. He is likely to have which of the following lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Transection of the right half of the spinal cord in the upper thoracic region.

The symptoms in the patient are those of Brown-Sequard syndrome.

  • Loss of pain and temperature on same side.
  • All other sensations lost on the opposite side.
  • Touch is least affected.
  • Motor paralysis on the same side.

Below level of lesion UMN type of paralysis, at level of lesion LMN type (“BULL”).

questions.text: Late slow EPSP in autonomic ganglia is due to action on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Peptide receptors

 

Late slow EPSP is due to the action of GnRH (peptide) on peptide receptors.

  • In response to acetylcholine release from the preganglionic neuron, two EPSPs were generated in the postganglionic neuron due to nicotinic (N) receptor activation. The first EPSP was below the threshold for eliciting an action potential, but the second EPSP was suprathreshold and evoked an action potential. This was followed by an IPSP, probably evoked by muscarinic (M2) receptor activation. The IPSP is then followed by a slower, M1-dependent EPSP, and this can be followed by an even slower peptide-induced EPSP.
  • Motor paralysis on the same side.

Below level of lesion UMN type of paralysis, at level of lesion LMN type (“BULL”).

questions.text: All of the following are seen in REM sleep except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) ­ ↑GABA

REM sleep is associated with ¯ Nor epinephrine, ¯ Serotonin and ­↑ Acetylcholine from the brain stem nuclei that form the reticular activating system. NREM sleep is associated with ­ ↑GABA from hypothalamus and decreased histamine.

In this model, wakefulness and REM sleep are at opposite extremes. When the activity of norepinephrine- and serotonin-containing neurons (locus coeruleus and raphe nuclei) is dominant, there is a reduced level of activity in acetylcholine- containing neurons in the pontine reticular formation leading to wakefulness. The reverse of this pattern leads to REM sleep.

A more even balance in the activity of these groups of neurons is associated with NREM sleep. Increases in GABA and decreases in histamine promote NREM sleep via deactivation of the thalamus and cortex. Wakefulness occurs when GABA is reduced and histamine is released.

questions.text: What is filtration fraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

GFR/ RPF

Filtration fraction is ratio of the GFR to the RPF. It is normally 0.16–0.20.

The GFR varies less than the RPF. When there is a fall in systemic blood pressure, the GFR falls less than the RPF because of efferent arteriolar constriction, and consequently the filtration fraction rises.

questions.text: Shown below is the time taken for adaptation by four different receptors. Which line most closely represents the Pacinian corpuscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pacinian corpuscle is a very rapidly adapting touch receptor and is specific for vibration and deep pressure (poking).

Line A is for a slowly adapting receptor, such as the joint capsule receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following component of the basal ganglia secretes excitatory neurotransmitter Glutamate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

subthalamic nucleus

Neurons of the subthalamic nucleus secrete glutamate. These project to Globus Pallidus external and internal segments.

choices.text: Suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus is involved
SCN receives information about the light-dark cycles via the retinohypothalamic fibers
Daylight causes an increase in secretion of melatonin from the pineal gland
Diurnal change in melatonin secretion from the pineal gland functions as timing signal to coordinate events with the light-dark cycle, including the sleep-wake cycle.

questions.text: All of the following are true about circadian rhythm except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Daylight causes an increase in secretion of melatonin from the pineal gland

Daylight causes a decrease in melatonin secretion from the pineal gland. Melatonin increases during night.

questions.text: All of the following cause a decrease in the frequency of the alpha rhythm except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

hypocarbia

Hypercarbia or increase in PCO2 level causes a decrease in frequency of the alpha rhythm.

questions.text: The PepT1 mechanism for absorption of di and tri-peptides requires which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

H+

The dipeptides and tripeptides are transported into enterocytes by a system known as PepT1 (or peptide trans- porter 1) that requires H+ instead of Na+.

In the enterocytes, the di- and tri-peptides are hydrolyzed by di and tripeptidases and the amino acids released plus the amino acids absorbed from the intestinal lumen and brush border are transported out of the enterocytes along their basolateral borders by at least five transport systems. From there, they enter the hepatic portal blood.

choices.text: Temporary loss of stretch reflexes below the lesion
Temporary loss of proprioception below the level of lesion
Permanent loss of movement above the level of lesion
Permanent loss of consciousness above the lesion

questions.text: Complete transection of the spinal cord at the level of T1 would most likely result in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Temporary loss of stretch reflexes below the lesion

Transection of the spinal cord will result in “spinal shock”. During this period there is a complete loss of all reflexes below the lesion. These reflexes, which are local circuits in the spinal cord, will return with time or become hypersensitive.

Spinal shock occurs from 0-24 hrs post injury. Caudal to the injury, deep tendon jerks are initially absent and muscles are flaccid and paralyzed. During this period cutaneous reflexes such as bulbocavernosus, cremasteric begin to recover. Sequence of recovery- delayed plantar reflex (abnormal reflex which lasts for several weeks) followed by bulbocavernosus and cremasteric.

choices.text: Graded responses depending on the stimulus intensity
Always bring the membrane potential of a receptor cell toward the threshold

questions.text: Sensory receptor potentials arebest described by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Graded responses depending on the stimulus intensity

Receptor potentials are graded responses and depend on the strength of stimulus. They may be depolarizing or hyperpolarizing and are not self-propagated.

choices.text: They area type of extrafusal muscle fibers
They give rise to group Ib afferents
They are innervated by Aα- motor neurons

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of nuclear chain fibers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

They detect steady muscle length

Nuclear chain fibers detect static length. Nuclear bag fibers are of two type- dynamic, for rate of change of muscle length and static, for steady length.

questions.text: Which reflex is responsible for monosynaptic excitation of ipsilateral homonymous muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

myotactic reflex

Myotactic reflex is a monosynaptic reflex which causes contraction of the ipsilateral homonymous muscle (same muscle on the same side).

questions.text: Maximum calcium reabsorption occurs in which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

PCT

Maximum calcium (65%) is reabsorbed in the PCT. 25-30% of the filtered calcium is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb. Calcium reabsorption in the DCT (4-9%) is under the control of parathormone. Less than 1% of the filtered calcium is excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following innervate the extensor alpha motor neuron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

vestibulospinal tract

Reticulospinal tracts synapse with A gamma motor neurons to the extensors.

Lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts innervate the A alpha neurons to the flexors. Vestibulospinal tract innervate the A alpha to the extensors.

choices.text: SCFAs are produced in colon by the action of colonic bacteria on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches and dietary fiber
SCFAs are absorbed in the colon
SCFAs are absorbed by Na-SCFA co transport

questions.text: All of the following are true about short chain fatty acids except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

SCFAs are absorbed by Na-SCFA co transport.

SCFAs are produced in colon by the action of colonic bacteria on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches and dietary fiber and are absorbed in the colon. 60% of total is acetate, 25% propionate, and 15% butyrate. Absorbed SCFAs are metabolized and make a significant contribution to the total caloric intake. They exert a trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cells. SCFAs are absorbed by specific transporters present in colonic epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is k/a the physiologic b- cell stimulating hormone of GI tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

GLP-1

The GI hormones which can increase insulin secretion are

  • GLP-1 (by L cells; also called physiologic b- cell stimulating hormone of GI tract)
  • GIP (by K cells; also called glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide)

The following have also been found to increase Insulin secretion

  • CCK
  • Secretin
  • Glucagon

GIP contains 42 amino acid residues and is produced by K cells in the mucosa of the duodenum and jejunum. Its secretion is stimulated by glucose and fat in the duodenum, and because in large doses it inhibits gastric secretion and motility, it was named gastric inhibitory peptide. However, it now appears that it does not have significant gastric inhibiting activity when administered in smaller amounts comparable to those seen after a meal. In the meantime, it was found that GIP stimulates insulin secretion. Gastrin, CCK, secretin, and glucagon also have this effect, but GIP is the only one of these that stimulates insulin secretion when administered at blood levels comparable to those produced by oral glucose. For this reason, it is often called glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide.

The glucagon derivative GLP-1 (7–36) also stimulates insulin secretion and is said to be more potent in this regard than GIP. Therefore, it may also be a physiologic B cell–stimulating hormone of the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Water is absorbed in the jejunum, ileum, and colon and excreted in the feces. Arrange these in order of the amount of water absorbed from greatest to smallest.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

jejunum, ileum, colon

The input into the GI tract is approximately 9000mL per day (Oral intake- 2000mL, GI secretions- 7000mL). Out of this 5500mL is absorbed in the jejunum, 2000mL in the ileum and 1300mL in the colon. Balance 200mL is lost in stool.

questions.text: Which of the following segments of the nephron is freely permeable to urea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

medullary CD

Urea contributes to the establishment of the osmotic gradient in the medullary pyramids and to the ability to form a concentrated urine in the collecting ducts. Urea transport is mediated by urea transporters, presumably by facilitated diffusion. There are at least four isoforms of the transport protein UT-A in the kidneys (UT-A1 to UT-A4); UT-B is found in erythrocytes and in the descending limbs of the vasa recta. Urea transport in the collecting duct is mediated by UT-A1 and UT-A3, and both are regulated by vasopressin. During antidiuresis, when vasopressin is high, the amount of urea deposited in the medullary interstitium increases, thus increasing the concentrating capacity of the kidney. In addition, the amount of urea in the medullary interstitium and, consequently, in the urine varies with the amount of urea filtered, and this in turn varies with the dietary intake of protein. Therefore, a high- protein diet increases the ability of the kidneys to concentrate the urine and a low-protein diet reduces the kidneys’ ability to concentrate the urine.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: Which of the following is the most alkaline?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Brunner’s gland secretion

Saliva has a pH of 6.0 to 8.0 (usually 7.0). gastric secretion is acidic with a pH of 2.0- 3.0. Pancreatic secretions have a pH of 8.8. Brunner’s gland secretions have a pH of up to 9.3.

questions.text: Maximum daily secretion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

gastric

  • Salivary secretion- 800- 1200 mL/day (1000- 1500mL/day)
  • Gastric secretion – 2500mL/day (2000- 2500mL/day)
  • Pancreatic- 1500mL/day

Intestinal- 1500mL/day (1500- 2000mL/day)

questions.text: Maximum frequency of BER is in which of the following segments of the GI tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

duodenum

The membrane potential of the majority of gastrointestinal smooth muscle undergoes rhythmic fluctuations that sweep along the length of the gut. The rhythm varies in different gut segments and is established by pacemaker cells known as interstitial cells of Cajal. This basic electrical rhythm (BER) provides for sites of muscle contraction when stimuli superimpose spike potentials on the depolarizing portion of the BER waves. The maximum frequency of the BER is in the duodenum at 12/min. The minimum frequency of BER is in the cecum at 2/min.

questions.text: In infants, defecation often follows a meal. The cause of colonic contractions in this situation is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

gastrocolic reflex

Distension of the stomach by food initiates contractions of the rectum and, frequently, a desire to defecate. The response is called the gastrocolic reflex, and may be amplified by an action of gastrin on the colon. Because of the response, defecation after meals is the rule in children. In adults, habit and cultural factors play a large role in determining when defecation occurs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important choleretic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

bile acids

Choleretics are substances that increase the secretion of bile.  Bile acids themselves are the most important choleretics. Secretin increases the bicarbonate content, and therefore, water in the bile- it is k/a a hydrocholeretic. CCK is a cholegogue- it causes contraction of the gall bladder. Production of bile is increased by the stimulation of the vagus nerve. CCK activates vagal afferents to trigger a vagovagal reflex that reinforces gall bladder contraction via release of acetylcholine and relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to permit bile outflow (via NO and VIP).

questions.text: Shown below is the graph of plasma concentration (mg/mL) and clearance (mL/min). Which of the following represents PAHA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Para amino hippuric acid in low concentration is freely filtered and completely secreted. The renal clearance of PAH at low concentration is very high. At low concentration, clearance of PAH is equal to the renal plasma flow. But as the plasma concentration of PAH increases there is an incomplete secretion of PAH, decreasing its clearance.

questions.text: Increase in which hormone will produce a change in urine osmolality and urine flow rate as shown in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

ADH

Increase in ADH increases water reabsorption, increasing urine osmolality and decreasing the urine flow rate.

questions.text: Which of the following shows a pattern of secretion as depicted in the adjacent diagram?
questions.solution:
​​​​​​Correct Answer (A) 

Testosterone in males

choices.text: diet lacking in essential fatty acids

questions.text: Normally, T3 > RT3. Which of the following dietary modification will cause RT3 to become more than T3?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

starvation

Normally, T3 > RT3 but in conditions of starvation, any prolonged illness, myocardial infarction, chronic kidney disease, etc., RT3 > T3.

In fasted individuals, plasma T3 is reduced by 10-20% within 24 hours and by about 50% in 3-7 days, with a corresponding rise in RT3. Free and bound T4 levels remain essentially normal. During more prolonged starvation, RT3 returns to normal but T3 remains depressed. At the same time, the BMR falls and urinary nitrogen excretion, an index of protein breakdown, is decreased. Thus, the decline in T3 conserves calories and protein, conversely overfeeding increases T3 and reduces RT3.

Fall in plasma T3 levels and a reciprocal rise in RT3 is seen in the following conditions:-

  • Selenium deficiency
  • Drugs which inhibit deiodinases
  • Burns
  • Trauma
  • Advanced cancer
  • Cirrhosis
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Myocardial infarction

Febrile states

questions.text: Given in the diagram are movements of the GI tract occurring at regular intervals during fasting and completely inhibited by a meal. These are
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Migrating motor complexes

MMC is a ring of contraction which starts from the body of stomach and upto the distal ileum. These are recorded in the fasting state. The first MMC is recorded 90-120 minutes after the last meal and then every 90 minutes.

Migrating motor complexes

  • Occur during fasting, in the inter digestive periods
  • It is a ring of contraction which starts from body of stomach to the distal ileum
  • Each cycle, or migrating motor complex (MMC), starts with a quiescent period (phase I), continues with a period of irregular electrical and mechanical activity (phase II), and ends with a burst of regular activity (phase III).
  • These are initiated by motilin.
  • Occur every 100 min in the interdigestive state.
  • Contractions migrate aborally at a rate of about 5 cm/min.
  • Gastric secretion, bile flow, and pancreatic secretion increase during each MMC- they likely serve to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal.
  • Conversely, when a meal is ingested, secretion of motilin is suppressed (ingestion of food suppresses motilin release via mechanisms that have not yet been elucidated), and the MMC is abolished, until digestion and absorption are complete. Instead, there is a return to peristalsis and the other forms of BER and spike potentials during this time.

The antibiotic erythromycin binds to motilin receptors, and derivatives of this compound may be of value in treating patients in whom gastrointestinal motility is decreased.

questions.text: Change in sex hormone binding globulin will most affect levels of which of these hormones?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Testosterone.

Testosterone is transported with the help of sex hormone binding globulin. Sex hormone binding globulin binds androgens and estrogen. Estrogen increases the level of SHBG. Estrogenic states such as, oral contraceptives, pregnancy, hyperthyroidism, cirrhosis, anorexia, certain drugs are associated with increased SHBG. DHEA does not require a protein for transport. Progesterone, cortisol and other steroids are transported by transcortin.

questions.text: Countercurrent mechanism is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

eye

Counter current mechanism is present in the kidney, testicular vessels, intestinal villi and in venae comitantes. Eye does not have a counter current mechanism.

choices.text: Change in angle   of joint   during    motion
Length of the muscle at rest
Change in length of muscle before and after the movement

questions.text: During voluntary movements Golgi tendon organ continuously relays which of the following to the efferent neurons:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)  

Golgi tendon organs are receptors for muscle tension.

choices.text: Urinary concentration of urea in g/24 hr
Urinary concentration of urea in mg/ ml

questions.text: In the formula for urea clearance, C= U x V/P, U denotes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Urinary concentration of urea in mg/ ml

U is urinary concentration of urea in mg/ml, V is the rate of urine flow in mL/min and P is the plasma concentration of urea in mg/mL.

choices.text: High control and less skilled movements
More muscle fiber units present in the movement

questions.text: Maximum area of representation in a homunculus signifies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Increased precise nature of movements

More complicated, well controlled and precise movements have larger cortical representation.

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.text: Which of the following is k/a diluting segment of kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

thick ascending limb of loop of henle

The descending thin segment of the loop of henle absorbs only water. Thick ascending limb absorbs only solutes. But the absorption of solutes in the TAL is more than the absorption of water in the descending limb,as a result of which the fluid which enters the DCT is hypotonic. TAL is, therefore, k/a the diluting segment of the nephron.

questions.text: Which extrapyramidal tract functions like the pyramidal tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Rubrospinal

Rubrospinal and lateral corticospinal tracts are the lateral descending tracts which control distal muscles and fine, skilled movements.

questions.text: Weber Fechner law states that the sensation felt is proportional to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

log of intensity of stimulus

Weber Fechner law states that the sensation felt is proportional to the log of intensity of stimulus.

questions.text: The thalamic relay nucleus for taste is
questions.solution:
​​​​​​Correct Answer (A) 

Ventroposteromedial

  • VPM is the relay nucleus for taste.
  • VPL is the relay nucleus for somatic sensations.
  • Dorsomedial thalamic is for olfaction.

Intralaminar is a non-specific sensory relay nucleus.

questions.text: Calcitonin is secreted by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Thyroid gland

Calcitonin, a calcium-lowering hormone, is secreted primarily by cells in the thyroid gland. Calcitonin receptors are present on osteoclasts and inhibits bone resorption. Although the role of calcitonin seems to be relatively minor, all three hormones- parathormone, 1,25- dihyrdroxycholecalciferol and calcitonin probably operate in concert to maintain the constancy of the calcium level in the body fluids.

questions.text: Gastric lipase is secreted by which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Chief cells

The most characteristic secretions derive from the glands in the fundus or body of the stomach. These contain the distinctive parietal cells, which secrete hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor; and chief cells, which produce pepsinogens and gastric lipase.
